sen.j: 日本二十六聖人（にほんにじゅうろくせいじん）とは慶長元年12月19日 (旧暦)（グレゴリオ暦1597年2月5日）、豊臣秀吉の命令によって長崎市で処刑された26人のカトリック信徒。
sen.e: Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan is 26 Catholics executed in Nagasaki City on February 5, 1597 by order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
The twenty-six Martyrs of Japan is 26 Catholics executed in Nagasaki City on February 5, 1597 by order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
The twenty-six Martyrs of Japan is 26 Catholics executed in Nagasaki City on February 5, 1597 by order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 日本でキリスト教の信仰を理由に最高権力者の指令による処刑が行われたのはこれが初めてであった。
sen.e: This was the first execution by order of the person in paramount authority in Japan because of Christianity.
This was the first execution issued by the order of the person in the highest authority in Japan because they believed in Christianity.
sen.cmt: by order of → issued by the order ofin paramount authority → in the highest authoritybecause of Christianity → because they believed in Christianity
sen.e: This was the first execution issued by the order of the person in the highest authority in Japan because they believed in Christianity.

sen.j: 26人は後にカトリック教会によって聖人の列に加えられたため、彼らは「日本二十六聖人」と呼ばれることになった。
sen.e: These 26 martyrs were canonized later by the Catholic Church and called "Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan".
These 26 martyrs were canonized later by the Catholic Church and called "The Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan."
sen.cmt: The を追加。ピリオドの位置を変更。
sen.e: These 26 martyrs were canonized later by the Catholic Church and called "The Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan."

sen.j: 二十六人のうち、日本人は二十名、スペイン人が四名、メキシコ人、ポルトガル人がそれぞれ一名であり、すべて男性であった。
sen.e: Twenty-six martyrs were all male consisted of 20 Japanese, 4 Spanish, 1 Mexican and 1 Portuguese.
The Twenty-six martyrs were all male, consisted of 20 Japanese, 4 Spanish, 1 Mexican and 1 Portuguese.
sen.cmt: The を追加。カンマを追加
sen.e: The Twenty-six martyrs were all male, consisted of 20 Japanese, 4 Spanish, 1 Mexican and 1 Portuguese.

sen.j: この出来事を「二十六聖人の殉教」という。
sen.e: This event was called "The martyrdom of the Twenty-Six saints"
This event is called "The martyrdom of the Twenty-Six Saints."
sen.cmt: was → isTwenty-Six saints → Twenty-Six Saintsピリオドを追加
sen.e: This event is called "The martyrdom of the Twenty-Six Saints."

sen.j: 当時は、キリシタン大名やキリシタンによって、寺社が焼かれたり僧侶が迫害されたり、逆に仏教を厚く信仰する大名の元ではキリシタンが迫害される事件が相次いでいた。
sen.e: In those days, a number of successive incidents happened such as setting fires to temples and shrines, and persecution of Buddhist monks by Christian feudal lords and Christians, or conversely, persecution of Christians under religious Buddhist feudal lords.

In those days, a succession of the following incidents occurred: Christian feudal lords and Christians set fire to temples and shrines and also persecuted Buddhist monks; or conversely, Christians were persecuted in the place where religious Buddhist feudal lords dominated.
sen.cmt: 「キリシタン大名やキリシタンによって」のかかりうけが曖昧だったため全体を変更。
sen.e: In those days, a succession of the following incidents occurred: Christian feudal lords and Christians set fire to temples and shrines and also persecuted Buddhist monks; or conversely, Christians were persecuted in the place where religious Buddhist feudal lords dominated.

sen.j: さらに宣教師や商人によって日本人が奴隷として奴隷貿易事件が発生し、ここに至って豊臣秀吉はバテレン追放令を発布した。
sen.e: Moreover, the incident of slave trade with Japanese as slave by missionaries and merchants happened, and finally, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI proclaimed edict expelling Jesuit missionaries.

In addition to that, a slave-trade incident occurred in which missionaries and merchants sold Japanese people into slavery, which finally made Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI decide to issue the order expelling Jesuit missionaries.
sen.cmt: Moreover → in addition to that前半を変更and finally, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI proclaimed edict → which finally made Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI decide to issue the order
sen.e: In addition to that, a slave-trade incident occurred in which missionaries and merchants sold Japanese people into slavery, which finally made Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI decide to issue the order expelling Jesuit missionaries.

sen.j: ただし、秀吉は南蛮貿易の実利を重視していたため、この時点では大規模な迫害は行われなかった。
sen.e: However, since Hideyoshi placed emphasis on practical advantage from trade with Spain and Portugal, extensive persecution was not executed at that time.
However, since Hideyoshi placed emphasis on the actual profit that he could receive from Japan's trade with Spain and Portugal, a great persecution was not executed at this point.
sen.cmt: practical advantage from trade with... → the actual profit that he could receive from Japan's trade with …extensive persecution → a great persecutionat that time → at this point
sen.e: However, since Hideyoshi placed emphasis on the actual profit that he could receive from Japan's trade with Spain and Portugal, a great persecution was not executed at this point.

sen.j: 黙認という形ではあったが宣教師たちは日本で活動を続けることができたし、キリシタンとなった日本人が公に棄教を迫られる事はなかった。
sen.e: Although as acquiesce, missionaries could continue their activities in Japan and Japanese who became Christian did not officially forced for renunciation.

The missionaries could continue their activities in Japan, actually in the way that their activities were overlooked, and the Japanese who became Christian did not officially forced to abjure their religion.
sen.cmt: Although as acquiesce → actually in the way that their activities were overlookedforced for renunciation → forced to abjure their religion
sen.e: The missionaries could continue their activities in Japan, actually in the way that their activities were overlooked, and the Japanese who became Christian did not officially forced to abjure their religion.

sen.j: しかし、1596年10月のサン＝フェリペ号事件をきっかけに、秀吉は1596年12月8日に再び禁教令を公布した。
sen.e: However, San Felipe Incident on October 1596 as a trigger, Hideyoshi proclaimed the Ban on Christianity on December 8, 1596.
However, when the San Felipe Incident occurred in October, 1596, Hideyoshi issued the Ban on Christianity on December 8, 1596 again.
sen.cmt: San Felipe Incident on October 1596 as a trigger → when the San Felipe Incident occurred in October, 1596,proclaimed → issuedagainを追加
sen.e: However, when the San Felipe Incident occurred in October, 1596, Hideyoshi issued the Ban on Christianity on December 8, 1596 again.

sen.j: また、フランシスコ会の活発な活動が禁教令に対して挑発的であると考え、京都奉行の石田三成に命じて、京都に住むフランシスコ会員とキリスト教徒全員を捕縛して処刑するよう命じた。
sen.e: He also thought Franciscan's brisk activities was provocative against the Ban and ordered to the Kyoto magistrate, Mitsunari ISHIDA to arrest and execute all Franciscan members and Christians.

Hideyoshi also thought that Franciscan's energetic activities were provocative against the Ban on Christianity and ordered to the Kyoto magistrate, Mitsunari ISHIDA, to arrest and execute all Franciscan members and Christians.
sen.cmt: thoughtの後にthatを追加brisk activities → energetic activitiesthe Ban → the Ban on Christianity
sen.e: Hideyoshi also thought that Franciscan's energetic activities were provocative against the Ban on Christianity and ordered to the Kyoto magistrate, Mitsunari ISHIDA, to arrest and execute all Franciscan members and Christians.

sen.j: ちなみに、二十六聖人のうち、フランシスコ会会員とされているのは、スペインのアルカンタラのペテロが改革を起こした「アルカンタラ派」の会員達であった。
sen.e: Franciscan members in Twenty-six martyrs were the members of "Alcantara group" in which Peter in Alcantara, Spain accomplished the reform.
The Franciscan members in the Twenty-six martyrs were the members of "the Alcantara group," one of whom, a Spanish man, St. Peter of Alcantara, arose a reform.
sen.cmt: the を追加後半を変更
sen.e: The Franciscan members in the Twenty-six martyrs were the members of "the Alcantara group," one of whom, a Spanish man, St. Peter of Alcantara, arose a reform.

sen.j: 大阪と京都でフランシスコ会員7名と信徒14名、イエズス会関係者3名の合計24名が捕縛された。
sen.e: A total of 24 people consisted of 7 Franciscan members and 14 supporters, and 3 people involved in the Society of Jesus were arrested in Osaka and Kyoto.
A total of 24 people consisted of 7 Franciscan members, 14 followers of the Franciscan, and 3 people involved in the Society of Jesus were arrested in Osaka and Kyoto.
A total of 24 people consisted of 7 Franciscan members, 14 followers of the Franciscan, and 3 people involved in the Society of Jesus were arrested in Osaka and Kyoto.

sen.j: 三成はパウロ三木を含むイエズス会関係者を除外しようとしたが、果たせなかった。
sen.e: Mitsunari tried to remove people involved in the Society of Jesus including Paul MIKI, but failed.
Mitsunari tried to remove people involved in the Society of Jesus including Paul MIKI, but failed.
Mitsunari tried to remove people involved in the Society of Jesus including Paul MIKI, but failed.

sen.j: 24名は、京都・堀川通り一条戻り橋で左の耳たぶを切り落とされて（秀吉の命令では耳と鼻を削ぐように言われていた）、市中引き回しとなった。
sen.e: The 24 people had their left ear cut off on Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge located at Horikawa-dori Street in Kyoto (Hideyoshi ordered to cut their ears and nose off) and dragged through the city streets.

The 24 people had their left ears cut off on Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge located at Horikawa-dori Street in Kyoto (Hideyoshi ordered to cut off their ears and noses) and were dragged through the city streets.
sen.cmt: cut their ears and nose off → cut off their ears and nosesdragged → were dragged
sen.e: The 24 people had their left ears cut off on Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge located at Horikawa-dori Street in Kyoto (Hideyoshi ordered to cut off their ears and noses) and were dragged through the city streets.

sen.j: 1597年1月10日、長崎で処刑せよという命令を受けて一行は大阪を出発、歩いて長崎へ向かうことになった。
sen.e: On January 10, 1597, they were ordered to be executed in Nagasaki and departed Osaka to Nagasaki on foot.
On January 10, 1597, they were ordered to be executed in Nagasaki and departed from Osaka to Nagasaki on foot.
On January 10, 1597, they were ordered to be executed in Nagasaki and departed from Osaka to Nagasaki on foot.

sen.j: また、道中でイエズス会員の世話をするよう依頼され付き添っていたペトロ助四郎と、同じようにフランシスコ会員の世話をしていた伊勢の大工フランシスコも捕縛された。
sen.e: In addition, Peter Sukejiro who was asked to attend Jesuits along the way and Francis, a carpenter from Ise, who was similarly attend Franciscan members were also arrested.

In addition, Peter Sukejiro who was asked to go along with the members of the Jesuits to take care of them, and Francisco, a carpenter from Ise, who also took care of the Franciscan members were arrested.
sen.cmt: asked to attend Jesuits along the way → asked to go along with the members of the Jesuits to take care of themFrancis → Franciscowho was similarly attend Franciscan members were also arrested → who also took care of the Franciscan members were arrested
sen.e: In addition, Peter Sukejiro who was asked to go along with the members of the Jesuits to take care of them, and Francisco, a carpenter from Ise, who also took care of the Franciscan members were arrested.

sen.j: 二人はキリスト教徒として、己の信仰のために命を捧げることを拒絶しなかった。
sen.e: They did not refuse to sacrifice their lives for their own religious belief as Christians.
They did not refuse to sacrifice their lives for their own religious belief as Christians.
They did not refuse to sacrifice their lives for their own religious belief as Christians.

sen.j: 厳冬期の旅を終えて長崎に到着した一行を見た責任者の寺沢半三郎は、一行の中に12歳の少年ルドビコ茨木がいるのを見て気の毒に思い、信仰を捨てることを条件に助けようとしたが、ルドビコはこの申し出を丁重に断った。
sen.e: The supervisor, Hanzaburo TERAZAWA, who found 12-year old Louis IBARAKI among the party arrived in Nagasaki after journey at midwinter, felt sorry and tried to save him in return to renunciation, but Louis politely turned down this offer.

When the supervisor, Hanzaburo TERAZAWA, found 12-year old Louis IBARAKI among the party which arrived in Nagasaki after the journey in the coldest period of winter, he felt sorry and tried to save him by offering the condition that he should renounce his religion, but Louis politely turned down this offer.
sen.cmt: 冒頭にWhenを追加whoを削除arrivedの前にwhichを追加journey at midwinter → the journey in the coldest period of winterfelt sorry → he felt sorryin return to renunciation → by offering the condition that he should renounce his religion
sen.e: When the supervisor, Hanzaburo TERAZAWA, found 12-year old Louis IBARAKI among the party which arrived in Nagasaki after the journey in the coldest period of winter, he felt sorry and tried to save him by offering the condition that he should renounce his religion, but Louis politely turned down this offer.

sen.j: ディエゴ喜斎と五島のヨハネは告解を聞くためにやってきたイエズス会員フランチェスコ・パシオ神父の前で誓願を立てて、イエズス会入会を許可された。
sen.e: James KISAI and John of Goto made their profession in front of a Jesuit, Father Francisco Pasio who came to hear their confession and gained admission to the Society of Jesus.
James KISAI and John of Goto made their profession in front of a Jesuit, Father Francisco Pasio, who came to hear their confessions, and gained admission to the Society of Jesus.
sen.cmt: their confession → their confessionsカンマを追加
sen.e: James KISAI and John of Goto made their profession in front of a Jesuit, Father Francisco Pasio, who came to hear their confessions, and gained admission to the Society of Jesus.

sen.j: 26人が通常の刑場でなく、長崎の西坂の丘の上で処刑されることが決まると、一行はそこへ連行された。
sen.e: It was determined that 26 martyrs would be executed on the hill of Nishizaka, Nagasaki, instead of usual execution ground, and the party was forcibly taken there.
When it was determined that the 26 martyrs would be executed on the hill of Nishizaka in Nagasaki instead of the execution ground where was usually used, the party was taken to the place.
sen.cmt: 冒頭にWhenを追加26 martyrs → the 26 martyrsNagasaki → in Nagasakiusual execution ground → the execution ground where was usually usedforciblyを削除there → to the place
sen.e: When it was determined that the 26 martyrs would be executed on the hill of Nishizaka in Nagasaki instead of the execution ground where was usually used, the party was taken to the place.

sen.j: 長崎市内は混乱を避けるため外出禁止令が出されていたが、4000人を超える群集がそこへ集まってきていた。
sen.e: Curfew was imposed in Nagasaki City to avoid confusion, but more than 4000 people gathered there.
A curfew was imposed in Nagasaki City to avoid confusion, but more than 4000 people gathered there.
A curfew was imposed in Nagasaki City to avoid confusion, but more than 4000 people gathered there.

sen.j: パウロ三木は死を目前にして群集に自分の信仰を語った。
sen.e: Paul MIKI told his own religious belief to the people facing his own death.
Paul MIKI told his own religious belief to the people when he was facing his own death.
Paul MIKI told his own religious belief to the people when he was facing his own death.

sen.j: 一行が槍に両脇を刺しぬかれて殉教したのは午前10時ごろであった。
sen.e: It was around 10 in the morning when they were martyred by piercing both sides of the body with the spear.
It was around 10 in the morning when they were martyred by being pierced both sides of the body with the spear.
It was around 10 in the morning when they were martyred by being pierced both sides of the body with the spear.

sen.j: 遺骸は死後、多くの人の手でわけられ、日本で最初の殉教者の遺骸として世界各地に送られて崇敬を受けた。
sen.e: After their death, the bodies were shared by many people to send all over the world as the bodies of the first martyrs in Japan and revered.
After their death, the bodies were divided by many people to send all over the world as the bodies of the first martyrs in Japan and revered.
After their death, the bodies were divided by many people to send all over the world as the bodies of the first martyrs in Japan and revered.

sen.j: これはカトリック教会において、殉教者の遺骸や遺物（聖遺物）を尊ぶ伝統があったためである。
sen.e: This is because Catholic Church had the tradition to respect the bodies and relics (sacred relics) of martyrs.
This is because Catholic Church had a tradition of respecting the bodies and relics (sacred relics) of martyrs.
sen.cmt: the → a to respect → of respecting
sen.e: This is because Catholic Church had a tradition of respecting the bodies and relics (sacred relics) of martyrs.

sen.j: 日本26聖人は近世においては、日本よりもヨーロッパにおいてよく知られていたが、それはルイス・フロイスなどの宣教師たちの報告書によるところが大きい。
sen.e: Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan are more famous in Europe than in Japan in modern times, which is due largely to reports by the missionaries such as Luis FROIS.
The Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan were more well known in Europe than in Japan in early-modern times, which is due largely to the reports written by the missionaries such as Luis FROIS.
sen.cmt: Twenty-six → The Twenty-sixfamous → well knownmodern times → early-modern timesreports → the reports
sen.e: The Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan were more well known in Europe than in Japan in early-modern times, which is due largely to the reports written by the missionaries such as Luis FROIS.

sen.j: 1862年6月8日、ローマ教皇ピウス9世 (ローマ教皇)によって列聖され、聖人の列に加えられた。
sen.e: On June 8, 1862, they were canonized by Pope Pius IX (pope) and made saints.
On June 8, 1862, they were canonized for saints by Pope Pius IX (pope) and added to the list of saints.
sen.cmt: canonized → canonized for saintsmade saints → added to the list of saints
sen.e: On June 8, 1862, they were canonized for saints by Pope Pius IX (pope) and added to the list of saints.

sen.j: 1962年には列聖100年を記念して西坂の丘に日本二十六聖人記念館（今井兼次の設計）と彫刻家の舟越保武による記念碑が建てられた。
sen.e: In 1962, for the 100th anniversary of canonization, Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (designed by Kenji IMAI) and commemoration by the sculptor, Yasutake FUNAKOSHI were built on the hill in Nishizaka.
In 1962, Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (designed by Kenji IMAI) and monument by the sculptor, Yasutake FUNAKOSHI were built on the hill in Nishizaka to commemorate the 100th anniversary of canonization.
sen.cmt: "for the 100th anniversary of canonization"を後方に移動させ、さらに "to commemorate the 100th anniversary of canonization"と変更。Commemoration → monument
sen.e: In 1962, Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (designed by Kenji IMAI) and monument by the sculptor, Yasutake FUNAKOSHI were built on the hill in Nishizaka to commemorate the 100th anniversary of canonization.

sen.j: （以下、二十六聖人記念碑の右側から順に列挙）
sen.e: (Here lists the names from the right side of the commemoration for Twenty-six Martyrs)
(Here lists the names, starting from the right side of the monument for the Twenty-six Martyrs)
sen.cmt: from → , starting fromcommemoration → monumentTwenty-six → The Twenty-six
sen.e: (Here lists the names, starting from the right side of the monument for the Twenty-six Martyrs)

sen.j: フランシスコ会員の世話をするため、一行に付き添い、道中で捕縛された。
sen.e: Attended the party to take care of Franciscan members and arrested along the way.
He accompanied the party to take care of the Franciscan members and arrested along the way.
He accompanied the party to take care of the Franciscan members and arrested along the way.

sen.j: ペトロ助四郎（またはペドロ助四郎）
日本人、イエズス会員の世話をするため一行に付き添い、道中で捕縛された。
sen.e: Japanese, attended the party to take care of Jesuits and arrested along the way.
A Japanese who accompanied the party to take care of the Jesuits and arrested along the way.
sen.cmt: Japanese, attended → A Japanese who accompanied
sen.e: A Japanese who accompanied the party to take care of the Jesuits and arrested along the way.

sen.j: ミカエル小崎（またはミゲル小崎）

sen.e: He was father of Thomas KOZAKI.
He was father of Thomas KOZAKI.
He was a brother of Leo KARASUMARU.
He was a brother of Leo KARASUMARU.

sen.j: 五島のヨハネ草庵（またはヨハネ五島）
sen.e: John Soan of Goto (or John of Goto)
John Soan of Goto (or John of Goto)
John Soan of Goto (or John of Goto)

sen.j: 大阪で捕縛、イエズス会員。
sen.e: He was a Jesuit who was arrested in Osaka.
He was a Jesuit who was arrested in Osaka.
He was 12 years old, the youngest Japanese.
He was 12 years old, the youngest Japanese.

sen.j: パウロ茨木、レオ烏丸の甥。
sen.e: Nephew of Paul IBARAKI and Leo KARASUMARU.
He was a nephew of Paul IBARAKI and Leo KARASUMARU.
He was a nephew of Paul IBARAKI and Leo KARASUMARU.

sen.j: 父は中国人、母は日本人。
sen.e: His father was Chinese and her mother was Japanese.
sen.cmt: 主語、動詞を加え、文章として体裁を整えました。
sen.e: His father was Chinese and her mother was Japanese.

sen.j: ペトロ・バウチスタ（またはペドロ・バプチスタ）
マルチノ・デ・ラ・アセンシオン
フェリペ・デ・ヘスス（またはフィリッポ・デ・ヘスス）
sen.e: Philip of Jesus (or Felipe de Jesús)
Philip of Jesus (or Felipe de Jesús)
Philip of Jesus (or Felipe de Jesús)

sen.j: フランシスコ会修道士。
フランシスコ会修道士。
フランシスコ・ブランコ
フランシスコ・デ・サン・ミゲル
フランシスコ会修道士。

sen.e: A Japanese who was arrested in Kyoto.
A Japanese who was arrested in Kyoto.

sen.j: 本来逮捕者のリストになかったが、洗礼名が同じというだけで捕縛。
sen.e: Originally not listed in the arrestee list, but arrested just because the Christian name was the same.
Originally, his name was not on the arrestee list, but he was arrested simply because he had the same Christian name.
sen.cmt: not listed in the arrestee list → his name was not on the arrestee listjust → simplythe Christian name was the same → he had the same Christian name
sen.e: Originally, his name was not on the arrestee list, but he was arrested simply because he had the same Christian name.
He was a younger brother of Paul IBARAKI.
He was a younger brother of Paul IBARAKI.
He was an uncle of Louis IBARAKI.
He was an uncle of Louis IBARAKI.
A Japanese who was arrested in Kyoto.
A Japanese who was arrested in Kyoto.
He was a child of Michael KOZAKI
He was a child of Michael KOZAKI

sen.j: ヨアキム榊原（またはホアキン榊原）
日本二十六聖人に捧げられた教会
sen.e: Church devoted to Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan
The church devoted to the Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan
The church devoted to the Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan

sen.j: 日本聖殉教者教会（LA CHIESA DEI SANTISSIMI MARTIRI GIAPPONESI）（イタリア チヴィタヴェッキア）
sen.e: Church for Japanese martyrs (LA CHIESA DEI SANTISSIMI MARTIRI GIAPPONESI) (Civitavecchia, Italy)
The Church of the Holy Japanese Martyrs (LA CHIESA DEI SANTISSIMI MARTIRI GIAPPONESI) (Civitavecchia, Italy)
sen.cmt: Church for Japanese martyrs → The Church of the Holy Japanese Martyrs
sen.e: The Church of the Holy Japanese Martyrs (LA CHIESA DEI SANTISSIMI MARTIRI GIAPPONESI) (Civitavecchia, Italy)

sen.j: 大浦天主堂（長崎県長崎市）
堂崎教会（長崎県五島市）
日本二十六聖人記念館（長崎県長崎市）、西坂教会ともいう。
sen.e: Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), also called Nishizaka Church.
Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), also called Nishizaka Church.
Twenty-six Martyrs Museum (Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), also called Nishizaka Church.
It was designed by Kenji IMAI.
It was designed by Kenji IMAI.

sen.j: 本所教会（東京都墨田区）
美濃加茂カトリック教会（岐阜県美濃加茂市）
sen.e: Minokamo Catholic Church (Minokamo City, Gifu Prefecture)
